title: Renee Zellweger discusses her iconic line from the '90s hit film Jerry Maguire
text:
Renee Zellweger delivered one of the most memorable lines in modern cinema alongside Tom Cruise in the 1996 hit film Jerry Maguire.

And as she promotes her Judy Garland biopic, the Oscar-winning actress reflected on being saddled with the now-famous phrase: 'You had me at hello.'

Speaking in an interview with The Project, the 50-year-old confessed, at the time, she never imagined how much of an impact the line would have on pop culture.

Flashback! Renee Zellweger (pictured) has reflected on being saddled with the now famous phrase: 'You had me at hello'

When co-host Waleed Aly asked Renee whether she had any idea of 'what she was unleashing' at the time when she delivered the line, she replied: 'No, not at all.'

'I never think about it that way. I just don't want to get fired,' she said, at which point the panel and audience burst into laughter.

Despite the audience's reaction, Renee went on to say that she was 'serious' and that it was imperative for her, at the time, to say the line correctly.

Surprised! When co-host Waleed Aly (right) asked Renee (left) whether she had any idea of 'what she was unleashing' at the time when she delivered the line, she replied: 'No, not at all'

'I just wanted to get it right and I knew it was really important to Cameron (Crowe) who directed the film,' Renee (left) told the co-hosts about her delivering the indelible line

'I just wanted to get it right and I knew it was really important to Cameron (Crowe) who directed the film,' she recalled.

Renee described how the one line took multiple takes to perfect, and several cues from Cameron, who was behind the camera shouting out directions across the set.

'It just kept rolling, rolling, rolling, and I was praying that I would just get it right once,' she said.

Outtakes! Renee (pictured in Jerry Magure) said the one line took multiple takes to perfect, and several cues from Cameron, who was behind the camera shouting out directions across the set

When the panel next asked whether the Oscar-winning actress would ever consider making another Bridget Jones reboot, she didn't completely dismiss the idea.

'Oh, gosh, yeah, wouldn't that be fun?' Renee quipped, referring to continuing the story from where her character left off in the last film: Bridget Jones' Baby.

'It's really the best job, it really is. So much weirder than folks can imagine from the outside,' she said.
